‚öôÔ∏è **Possessive pronouns** replace a noun and indicate possession. They agree in gender and number with the possessed object (not with the possessor).

üîπ **Forms of possessive pronouns:**

**Single possessor:**
- **m√≠o/m√≠a/m√≠os/m√≠as** ‚Üí mine

**Multiple possessors:**
- **nuestro/nuestra/nuestros/nuestras** ‚Üí ours
- **vuestro/vuestra/vuestros/vuestras** ‚Üí yours (plural informal)
- **suyo/suya/suyos/suyas** ‚Üí theirs (also: yours formal)

üîπ **Usage with definite article:**
Possessive pronouns are ALWAYS used with the definite article (el, la, los, las).

‚û°Ô∏è *Este libro es el m√≠o.* (This book is mine.)

üîπ **Difference from possessive adjectives:**

‚ö†Ô∏è **Watch out for SUYO:**
*Suyo/suya/suyos/suyas* can mean: his, hers, theirs, yours (formal).
To clarify, you can say:
